title: European countries face growing pressure to seize frozen Russian assets
summary: Political leaders are increasingly saying they want to use the €210 billion in frozen assets of the Central Bank of the Russian Federation to finance military aid to Ukraine.

title: Ukraine ready to accept 30-day ceasefire as US says 'ball is now in Russia's court'
summary: Ukraine and the United States were engaged in talks in Saudi Arabia on Tuesday, with Kyiv agreeing to a 30-day ceasefire proposed by the US. The Trump administration said it would immediately lift its suspension of military aid and intelligence sharing with the war-torn country.

title: PSG stun Liverpool on penalties to reach Champions League quarter-finals
summary: Never in Liverpool's history had they lost a European tie after winning the first leg away from home, but Ousmane Dembélé's early strike brought the French champions level at 1-1 on aggregate, and Paris Saint-Germain wound up winning 4-1.

title: Trump halts doubling of tariffs on Canadian metals, after Ontario suspends electricity price hikes
summary: The US president shocked markets Tuesday morning by saying that the increase of the tariffs set to take effect on Wednesday had been a response to the 25% price hike that Ontario put on electricity sold to the United States.

title: In France, one billionaire's media empire sides with Russia
summary: Since Donald Trump has made overtures to Moscow and JD Vance has proclaimed that free speech is threatened in Europe, the far-right broadcasters and newspapers owned by Vincent Bolloré are backing Vladimir Putin.

title: 'Gray divorces': They lived happily, had lots of children, and then split up when they were old enough to be grandparents
summary: After decades together, their marriages are ending at age 50 in a "gray divorce," like the color of their hair. On the increase, these late separations reflect a growing quest for personal fulfillment, turning family balances upside down.

title: Portugal government loses no-confidence vote, possibly setting up new elections
summary: The Socialist Party (PS), the main opposition party, and the far-right Chega party both voted to bring down the government, and the country's president Marcelo Rebelo de Sousa must now decide whether to dissolve the assembly and call new elections.

title: US House sends Senate must-pass bill to avert government shutdown
summary: The threat of a weekend shutdown comes with Wall Street reeling under Trump's trade war and radical cuts to federal spending that have seen tens of thousands of layoffs.

title: After the collision between an oil tanker and a cargo ship in the North Sea, 'the contradictory information about the cargoes is surprising'
summary: Nicolas Tamic, deputy director and head of operations at Cedre, the authority responsible for combating marine pollution in France, analyzes the possible consequences, particularly for the environment.

title: Donald Trump steps up a trade war aimed at throttling Canada economically
summary: The US president had pledged a 50% tariff on Canadian steel and aluminum imports. And threatened to go after its auto industry. This is more than just a trade dispute.

title: 'Hollywood has always been flexible enough to preserve its economic interests'
summary: In his column, Le Monde journalist Thomas Sotinel describes and imagines an upheaval in the American industry brought about by Trump's return to the White House.

title: How climate change affects volcanoes
summary: Researchers have found that half of all active volcanoes are exposed to the risk of torrential rains linked to climate change.

title: Wall Street plunges into doubt over risk of 'Trump recession'
summary: President Donald Trump's refusal, on Fox News, to rule out the possibility of a downturn in the US economy sent the stock market tumbling on Monday. Inflation is persistent and consumers are worried.

title: UK makes manslaughter arrest of cargo ship's captain after North Sea crash
summary: British police said they had arrested a man on suspicion of manslaughter after a missing member of one of the crews was declared 'likely deceased,' on Tuesday.

title: NASA fires climate researcher Katherine Calvin, the agency's chief scientist
summary: The co-chairwoman of the Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) was appointed in 2022 to advise the leadership of the US space agency on science-related programs and investments. In all, some 20 positions will be affected by the NASA cuts, announced Tuesday.

title: Greenland holds election in shadow of Trump
summary: The inhabitants of the autonomous Danish territory are going to the polls on Tuesday to elect their parliament. Among the issues that dominated the election campaign were independence and relations with Denmark.

title: Jorgen Boassen, Greenland's version of Trumpism
summary: A few weeks after he canvassed for Donald Trump on the streets of Pittsburgh, Pennsylvania, the 51-year-old Greenlandic builder was tasked with organizing Donald Trump Jr's January visit to Nuuk, the capital.

title: Macron's paradox: Calling for European sovereignty while letting France's finances slip
summary: Can France, an over-indebted nation, sustainably place itself at the forefront of the fight for sovereignty? This question concerns not only the president, but all political parties and citizens, writes Le Monde columnist Françoise Fressoz.

title: Polls close in Greenland's capital for parliamentary election as Trump seeks control
summary: Once the unofficial election results come in, they won't be certified for weeks as paper ballots make their way to the capital from remote settlements by boat, plane and helicopter.

title: EU reinforcements arrive as partition fears rise in Bosnia
summary: Since the end of Bosnia's inter-ethnic war in the 1990s, the Balkan country has consisted of two autonomous halves – the Serb-dominated RS and a Muslim-Croat region.

title: Friedrich Merz, German chancellor before his time
summary: Even though negotiations to form a coalition have not yet begun, the head of the Christian Democratic Union party, which came out on top in Germany's February 23 elections, has already embarked on major projects in his country and abroad.

title: Trump administration to halve staff at Education Department
summary: The US president promised to decentralize education as he campaigned for a return to the White House, saying he would devolve the department's powers to state governments

title: Pakistan launches major operation to free train hostages in Balochistan
summary: After armed militants hijacked a train on Tuesday, Pakistan has launched a 'full-scale' operation to free hostages who were being guarded by suicide bombers. A government spokesman has described the attack as 'an act of terrorism.'

title: 'Miss, will there be a war?': Global upheavals and Trump in the classroom
summary: As with every geopolitical crisis, teachers in France have to answer their pupils' questions. In high school, the syllabus is constantly impacted by current events.

title: A kaleidoscopic Paris Fashion Week
summary: The understated luxury of Hermès, the gothic-chic of McQueen, the baroque style of Valentino, the disquieting normality of Balenciaga: A wide array of styles was on display on the French capital's catwalks during the Fall-Winter 2025-2026 Fashion Week.

title: 'The fact that the debate on a European nuclear deterrent is open shows the extent of the current upheaval'
summary: Threatened by a potential withdrawal of the American umbrella, Germany and Poland are calling on France for its nuclear deterrence, writes Le Monde columnist Sylvie Kauffmann.

title: Ukraine accepts US proposal for 30-day ceasefire, stepping back into diplomatic game
summary: The Trump administration is awaiting a response from the Kremlin on this temporary cessation of hostilities, a prerequisite for peace negotiations. The agreement on Ukrainian minerals, which had seemed to be a priority for Washington, has taken a back seat.

title: Macron seizes on international situation to return to political limelight in France
summary: On March 13, the French president will convene the prime minister and seven other ministers at the Elysée Palace to discuss defense spending. Nine months after his failed dissolution of the Assemblée, he has returned to the national political scene.

title: From the US to Ukraine, King Charles III's careful diplomacy
summary: The monarch is a trump card in the British government's bid to avoid tariffs on exports to the US, while showing his support for Volodymyr Zelensky.

title: Trial of teen who killed his parents comes before French juvenile court
summary: The trial of Valentin, who was 15 when he killed his parents and set fire to their family home in southeastern France in 2023, opened on Tuesday. Experts concluded that his judgment was impaired at the time of the crime.

title: Greenland, coveted by Trump, sees surprise victory of center-right opposition in parliamentary elections
summary: Held amid an unprecedented geopolitical context, the March 11 elections saw the incumbent coalition lose out to the Demokraatit party and the nationalist Naleraq party. The campaign focused mainly on social issues.

title: Israel's opposition is powerless against Netanyahu and his far-right allies
summary: Seventeen months after the start of the war in Gaza, the once-powerful centrist and left-wing parties are still unable to come up with an alternative policy to that of the prime minister's coalition.

title: EU hits back at Trump's tariffs with taxes on up to €26 billion worth of American goods
summary: The European Union has announced tariffs on hundreds of products made in the US – from chewing gum to bidets – in retaliation for Washington's measures on aluminum and steel.

title: Russia remains cautious after US ceasefire proposal
summary: Russian President Vladimir Putin did not react to the truce proposal on Tuesday, while the foreign minister's comments were ambivalent.

title: NASA astronauts stuck in space closer to coming home after new ISS launch
summary: Suni Williams and Butch Wilmore have been stranded on the International Space Station since June after their spacecraft developed issues. The plan is for them to be onboard the returning mission for a SpaceX capsule taking off from  Florida on Wednesday.

title: Le Scouarnec child abuse trial: 'Pedophilia was consuming me'
summary: Colleagues and former superiors of the surgeon on trial for rape and sexual assault of 299 victims, most of them minors, insist that they never saw any evidence of his pedophilia.

title: US trading partners hit back on steel, aluminum tariffs
summary: The European Commission unveiled retaliation starting in April, Canada announced additional tariffs on US goods and China vowed 'all necessary measures' in response – as Washington edged toward an all-out trade war with allies and competitors alike.

title: Pakistan says insurgent attack on a train has ended but some hostages killed
summary: Officials announced that over 300 hostages were rescued and the operation had concluded on Wednesday, a day after armed militants hijacked a train. Some 50 attackers were killed, as well as a number of hostages.

title: The UK questions its nuclear deterrent, which depends on the US
summary: Although unthinkable just a few weeks ago, a debate is now taking shape on the possibility of calling into question the long-standing partnership with the United States and its implications.

title: Duterte arrives in the Netherlands to face ICC charges, says he's 'responsible'
summary: The former Philippines president faces charges of crimes against humanity over his war on drugs.

title: 'Very broad consensus' emerging among Europeans on Ukraine
summary: The defense ministers of Europe's five main military powers – France, Britain, Germany, Italy and Poland – acknowledged on Wednesday the challenges posed by the new administration of Donald Trump in the US, which is seeking direct talks with Russia to end the war sparked by the Russian 2022 invasion of Ukraine, while insisting Europe was ready to stand on its own feet.

title: Putin urges army to 'liberate' Kursk region as Ukraine pulls back
summary: In his first visit to the region since Ukraine launched its shock counter-offensive in August, Russian President Vladimir Putin, dressed in army camouflage, hailed recent gains and urged his troops on. The Kremlin said it was awaiting details of a US-Ukrainian proposal agreed this week, and gave no indication of its readiness to stop fighting that has left tens of thousands dead in the past three years.
